metadata.title: Progress in Triboelectric Materials: Toward High Performance and Widespread Applications

sections.text:
REVIEW www.afm-journal.de
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1900098 (1 of 27)
Progress in Triboelectric Materials: Toward High Performance and Widespread Applications
Aifang Yu, Yaxing Zhu, Wei Wang, and Junyi Zhai*
Triboelectric phenomena can be observed everywhere; however, they are consistently omitted from applications. Although almost all substances exhibit a triboelectrification effect in daily life, chemists as well as materials scientists have performed extensive investigations in both the aspects of basic science and practical applications to promote the development of triboelectric nanogenerators (TENGs). Here, a detailed survey of materials engineering for high triboelectric performance and multifunctional materials toward specific applications is summarized, including constructing micro/ nanostructures, chemically modifying the frication surface, modulating bulk friction materials, the mechanism for improved performance, and preparing materials for implantable medical devices, bionic skin, and wearable electronic devices. Moreover, an in depth discussion of the current challenges and future efforts for strengthening the performance of TENGs is elaborated in detail, which will better guide new researchers toward a deeper understanding of and explorations about TENGs.
DOI: 10.1002/adfm.201900098
urgently needed to alleviate a more severe energy crisis, which has diverted extensive attention toward renewable energy (solar energy, geothermal energy, etc.) by virtue of its large quantity and ubiquitous existence in our environment.[1–9] In addition, the rapid development of science and technology has also suggested higher requirements for energy delivery. In the past few decades, large numbers of mobile communication electronics, smart wearable devices, and internet of things (IoT) devices based on tens of thousands of sensors have appeared in every corner of the globe. These electronic devices are usually characterized by requiring a small amount of power, only on the microwatt or even the milliwatt level, whereas they hold a relatively large shape to facilitate frequent charging or battery replacement for embedded traditional solid-state power
sources. It is, therefore, desirable to integrate an energy harvester together with a battery to form a self-powered system that could be recharged by absorbing and transferring external fragmental energy. Furthermore, considering that a majority of these electronic devices are closely contacting the human body, the individualization of the energy-supply mode related to the person itself remains to be studied in depth.
To tackle energy shortages and content-specific power supply requirements, researchers have designed a diversity of energyconversion devices derived from assorted working principles to collect energy, such as solar cells, electromagnetic generators, thermoelectric generators, piezoelectric nanogenerators, and triboelectric nanogenerators (TENGs).[10–21] Primarily benefiting from their light weight, low cost, multiple structures, extensive material selection, and even great efficiency at low operating frequencies, the novel TENGs have been proven as up-and-coming candidates to complementarily solve the energy- deficiency issue. These devices can be applied to harvest all kinds of energy, ranging from clean natural energy to ubiquitous mechanical power and from slight acoustic flow to faint heart beats, showing their remarkable compatibility with severe environments and the human body, along with possibilities that still remain to be further explored.[22–32] The principle of triboelectric devices lies in the coupling effect of contact electrification and electrostatic induction, by which static polarized charges originating from friction bring about inductive charges among electrodes and drive them to transfer between counterparts within contact surface separation to fulfill the transition process from mechanical energy to electricity.[26,33–37]
Triboelectric Nanogenerators
Dr. A. Yu, Y. X. Zhu, W. Wang, Prof. J. Y. sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Nothing is of more paramount importance than energy with regard to sustaining human life, combating global climate change and creating economic prosperity. Along with the rapid progress in technology and exponential population growth, the energy structure around the world tends to experience a dramatic change due to increasing consumption demands, and traditional sources, such as coal and oil, progressively become insufficient for high-quality daily life. Conversely, cheap, abundant, and environmentally benign energy resources are
Adv. Funct. Mater. 2019, 1900098
1900098 (2 of 27) © 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
In essence, the theoretical basis of these devices can be derived from Maxwell’s displacement current and the change in surface polarization.[38] As a result of increasingly perfected theory ever since the first report of TENGs in January 2012, the performance of TENGs has been markedly promoted. To date, for an advanced triboelectric system, the area power density can reach 1200 W m−2, volume density further extends to 490 kW m−3, and instantaneous conversion efficiency of ≈50%–85%.[36,39,40] It is critical to highlight that the voltage and current output for four distinguished TENG working modes are proportional to the triboelectric charge density generated on contact surfaces, and accordingly, the output power shows a quadratic dependence on the charge density.[33–35,37] There are a vast number of materials, ranging from polymers to metals, exhibiting essentially triboelectric character, which gives rise to numerous methods toward performance enhancement from a microscopic perspective. Thus, to some extent, the development of TENGs dramatically motivates chemists as well as materials scientists to conduct extensive investigations in both the aspects of basic science and practical applications.
In brief, the previous studies from the material aspect could be mainly classified into two categories. On the one hand, substantial efforts are channeled to boost the output of TENGs by building up charge density and preventing transfer loss within varied triboelectric materials (ranging from surface to bulk configuration), including optimized matching of friction pairs in accordance with electron affinity and surface modification via either physical or chemical techniques.[41–49] Note that the micro/nanostructure constructed on the object surface, such as nanotubes or a polymer matrix, extrinsically reinforces the electrification process, serving as a complementary but useful option. On the other hand, the restricted application of conventional harvesters on stiff conformal substrates leaves much room for the exploration of stretchable, wearable, and implantable materials, opening doors for new kinds of biomechanical energy harvesters and sensor systems.[16,24,26,44,50–54] For instance, various TENG-based electronic skin and implantable medical devices have so far been gradually brought out and upgraded by experimenters, which considerably pave the way for next-generation electronics. Here, this review focuses on the tremendous endeavors that have been devoted to improving the triboelectric performance of materials and broadening the application scope of TENGs over the past years. We first give a short summary of the progress in materials optimization and discuss how and why they lead to differences in performance after modification. Then, the processes of progressing multifunctional material toward specific applications are selectively summarized. Finally, we highlight the challenges and future research directions of triboelectric materials and expect this to be conducive to related scientific research.

sections.heading: 2. Materials Optimization for High Triboelectric Performance
sections.text:
Theoretical simulation indicates that the output power of the TENG has a quadratic relationship with the surface triboelectric charge density.[55,56] Thus, one of the key approaches to better TENGs’ electrical performance is basically increasing triboelectric charge density from the materials perspective. It is well known that triboelectrification is one kind of surface effect and that friction materials and surface morphology can decisively determine the output of TENGs. Typically, in electricity generation processing, the charges in the friction layer of the TENG work as the source of electrostatic induction. In fact, after the triboelectric electrons are produced, the density of electrons at the surface of the friction layer will decrease gradually due to discharging effects, which can be attributed to drift, diffusion, air breakdown, and charge recombination.[41,42,57] The loss of these charges leads to a decline in the electrical potential difference between two TENG electrodes, thereby greatly deteriorating the output performance. As a result, essentially

Nanosystems (BINN), Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS) as an associate professor. Her main research interests focus on the fields of nanogenerators and self-powered nanosystems.
Adv. Funct. Mater. 2019, 1900098
1900098 (3 of 27) © 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
two routes toward enhancing the outputs of TENGs can be mentioned. One is directly increasing triboelectric charges through the choice of materials and surface engineering. The other is cutting down on unnecessary loss via bulk material modulation. To make it clear, this review will introduce a material optimization process along the abovementioned routes and the mechanism of these modification methods. The triboelectric performance of TENGs based on different physical or chemical techniques reported in recent literature reports has been also summarized in Table 1.

sections.heading: 2.1. Choice of Materials
sections.text:
It is well known that almost all materials have triboelectric effects, from wood, to polymers, to metals and to silk. According to the operating principle of the TENG, these materials can all be used as the friction layers of TENGs. Therefore, the possible friction material pairs are innumerable. However, not every pair of materials can produce high output. In the material aspect, high output is strongly dependent on the polarity difference of material pairs. Fortunately, in 1757, the first triboelectric series on static charges was published by John Carl Wilcke, who reported the polarity ability of different materials.[58,59] Some of these series are shown in Figure 1. The closer the material is to the bottom of the sequence, the easier it is to obtain electrons with negative charge. Moreover, the closer the material is to the top of the sequence, the easier it is to obtain positive electricity. The triboelectric series can guide researchers to select optimized triboelectric material pairs to obtain high output performance according to the application field. For example, a material with fluorine functional groups can attract as many electrons as possible from their counterparts. Yoon et al. reviewed
studies on TENGs based on polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE), fluorinated ethylene propylene (FEP), perpluoroalkoxy alkane (PFA), and polyvinyldinefluoride (PVDF), which exhibit high conversion efficiency and output power.[44] On the other hand, the design of some special TENGs for different application purposes can also benefit from this list. For example, silk and
Adv. Funct. Mater. 2019, 1900098
1900098 (4 of 27) © 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
paper, which are prone to the loss of electrons, are environmentally friendly and can be used to prepare biodegradable TENG.[60,61] Therefore, material selection is the first step for the fabrication of TENGs. When we select a pair, the charge characteristics and the output characteristics of the TENG could be predicted.

sections.heading: 2.2. Surface Engineering
sections.text: Controlling the charge density on triboelectric surfaces is the most fundamental strategy for improving the performance of TENGs. For triboelectric surfaces with a defined material, the number of charge carrying species and their ability to lose or gain electrons determine the surface charge density. Therefore, the aim of surface engineering is not only to increase the number of locations that can generate charge but also to strengthen the capturing capability of the locations through morphologically and chemically modifying the triboelectric surfaces.

sections.heading: 2.2.1. Modifying Surface Morphology
sections.text:
Morphological modification mainly refers to constructing micro/nanostructures on the friction surface. The contribution of micro/nanostructures to enhanced electrical performance is attributed to enlarging the effective triboelectric area, increasing the effective dielectric constant and raising the dipole moment between the electrodes.
Fan et al. first introduced micropatterns onto tribosurfaces and opened the door to high surface triboelectric charges by enlarging the friction area.[48] In their work, patterned (100) Si wafers constructed by a traditional photolithography method serve as the mold to create a modified polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) friction layer with features such as patterned pyramids, cubes, and lines, as shown in Figure 2a. To avoid the PDMS film sticking to the master, the surfaces of all molds
were first coated with trimethylchlorosilane. Second, the liquid PDMS cross-linker and elastomer were well and uniformly mixed, thoroughly degassed, and then spin-coated onto the surface of the molds one by one. After cooling to room temperature naturally, uniform patterned PDMS layers could be peeled off from the master with the designed surface morphology. Third, the PDMS films were stuck to polyethylene terephthalate (PET) substrates through a thin PDMS bonding layer. An indium tin oxide (ITO) layer was coated to the other side of the PET substrate to serve as the bottom electrode. Finally, the patterned surface was covered by using another ITO-coated PET thin film to form the TENG structure. Figure 2b contrasts the output performance of TENGs with those of various PDMS surface morphologies. The testing results reveal that the output amplitude increases following the series of film, line, cube, and pyramid. In particularly, if the TENGs are operated at 0.33 Hz under an external strain of 0.13%, the maximum output current and voltage for the pyramid-patterned TENG device are 0.7 µA and 18 V, respectively, which are nearly three times higher than those of the smooth film-based TENG.
Since then, optimized interfacial micro/nanostructures have been designed to further enhance surface charge density through developed physical and/or chemical methods. Nanowires (NWs) were then introduced to the polymer surface by Zhu et al. to enhance the output performance of the TENG device.[62] The aligned Kapton NWs with large aspect ratios are fabricated through simple plasma-enhanced ion etching processing (inductively coupled plasma; ICP).[63] Before the ICP etching course, the Kapton polymer films were physically deposited with different thicknesses of gold (Au) as the mask. The length and density of the Kapton NWs can be tuned by controlling the plasma processing time and the thickness of the deposited mask metal layer. The prepared Kapton polymer films are ion-milled by using oxygen (O2), carbon tetrafluoride (CF4), and argon (Ar) as the etching gases. As a result, the morphology under different etching times and related output voltages and currents is displayed in Figure 3a,b. It should be highlighted that only NWs of a suitable length (hundreds of
Adv. Funct. Mater. 2019, 1900098
1900098 (5 of 27) © 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
nanometers) benefit electric outputs because their elastic property retains the fixed morphology and orientation even after numerous separations and contacts, as revealed in Figure 3c. However, lengthy NWs fabricated under an excessive etching period are likely to produce strain at their root and hence exceed the elastic limit of the polymer tribomaterial, which forms permanent deformation and damages the surface pattern. Consequently, the surface cannot effectively generate friction-induced charges, which limits the output improvement in TENGs.
Lee and co-workers employed block copolymer technology to fabricate micro/nanostructures, which induce phase separation of covalently linked polymers and overcome additional limitations, thus realizing a high spatial resolution of nanoscale patterns such as rings, dots, holes, and lines, as shown in Figure 3d.[64] When a 50 N vertically compressive force was applied, the flat-surface TENG could only produce short-circuit current (ISC) and open-circuit voltage (VOC) values of 1.1 mA m−2 and 63 V, respectively. By contrast, the current density/voltage
of the block copolymer-patterned TENGs with nanogrates, nanodots, and nanomeshes reached 2.3 mA m−2/110 V, 1.8 mA m−2/95 V, and 2.8 mA m−2/130 V, respectively.
In addition, spongy/porous structures also exhibit a high capability to promote electric output. Lee et al. utilized polystyrene (PS) microspheres to fabricate PDMS sponges with pore sizes ranging from 0.5 to 10 µm, as shown in Figure 4a.[65] The researchers first fabricated a layer of PS microspheres on top of a SiO2/Si substrate and encapsulated them with PDMS. Then, they carefully removed the PS microspheres by an etching technique and transferred the as-fabricated sponge layer on the top of the Al electrode. A tremendous current density of 0.10 mA cm−2 and voltage output up to 130 V could be obtained from this sponge-structure TNG (STNG) in comparison to a flat TENG (0.02 mA cm−2 and 50 V) under the same measurement conditions. The enhanced electrical performance of the STNG is due to the shrinkage pores, which can be ascribed to the dramatically enhanced contact area at the

Reproduced with permission.[64] Copyright 2014, American Chemical Society.
1900098 (6 of 27) © 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
surface. Inspired by this result, Chun et al. reported a scalable and facile fabrication method for porous films by impregnating gold nanoparticles (NPs) as effective dielectrics to promote the performance of TENGs, which are elucidated in Figure 4b.[66] This method is scalable and quite simple and therefore provides a promising way to develop mass-producible and largescale self-powered devices based on TENGs. The as-fabricated TENG demonstrates a maximum power of 13 mW, which is more than a fivefold enhancement compared to that of a flat film-based TENG due to the aligned dipoles stemming from the inner contact of PDMS and Au NPs. Both of the proposed structures are infirmly sensitive to environmental humidity, demonstrating that this structure can be used in critical environments, for example, under high-humidity conditions or in water.
Moreover, there exist some facile templates to simply construct micro/nanostructures. Figure 5 gives a brief survey of some representative results. In Figure 5a, the fabrication process of polypropylene (CPP) nanopillars through an anodic aluminum oxide (AAO) template and their corresponding performance are elucidated.[67] The structure of the CPP nanopillars exerts great influence on the triboelectric effect. The nanopillars over 3 µm in length tend to bend and therefore inhibit the triboelectric effect. By contrast, for nanopillars with lengths ranging from 1 to 3 µm, there is no obvious difference in TENG outputs. Additionally, the pillar diameter plays
a pivotal role in altering the triboelectrification effect. The output current and voltage of devices are significantly boosted as the pillar diameter becomes larger due to the extra overlapping surface area under pressure. Another PDMS nanopattern from zinc oxide (ZnO) nanorods (NRs), which are fabricated on a silver-coated textile template, was applied for preparing fully flexible, foldable and wearable TENGs by Seung et al., as shown in Figure 5b.[68] This nanopattern was constructed by combining a low-temperature hydrothermal fabrication method for the ZnO NR with a subsequent dip-coating processing of the PDMS solution. An excellent output of approximately 65 µA and 120 V was realized by this nanopatterned wearable TENG, whereas the output performance of the plain PDMS-based WTNG was only 20 µA and 30 V under the same mechanical force and frequency. Figure 5c displays a novel structure using natural leaves as the template.[69] In addition, techniques such as thermal imprinting lithography, hot embossing, or utilization of transfer-printable micropatterns, sand paper templates and 2D colloidal self-assembly of microparticles have been further reported to create micro/nanostructures on polymer surfaces for the enhancement in TENG output performance.[70–77]
In fact, triboelectric materials include not only polymers, but also metals, metal-oxide semiconductors, silk, cotton, wood, etc.[45] Similarly, surface engineering on nonpoly mer also works great to improve the output performance. In Figure 6a, Zhu et al. originally introduced an NP-based
Adv. Funct. Mater. 2019, 1900098

KGaA, Weinheim. b) High performance TENG based on mesoporous pores impregnated with Au nanoparticles as effective dielectrics. Reproduced with permission.[66] Copyright 2015, Royal Society of Chemistry.
1900098 (7 of 27) © 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
modification technique on metal surfaces to promote the electricity output.[78] In their research, chemically synthesized gold NPs self-assemble onto the surface of an Au thin film and act as a pivotal part for the output enhancement. As a result, compared to the TENG without modifications of the metal surface, it renders a fivefold current enhancement and 25 times power enhancement since the rough surface with NPs offers a dramatically larger contact surface area than a simply flat surface does. Likewise, in Figure 6b, another simple but effective way to reshape the metal surface was introduced by Park et al. with the help of a water-assisted oxidation (WAO) process.[79] Instead of complicated treatments or equipment, this onestep WAO processing only requires hot water, by which highdensely packed micro and/or nanostructures were generated on various target metal surfaces: zinc, aluminum, and copper. Specifically, the WAO material on aluminum had grass-like nanostructures, the WAO material on the copper substrate had cubic-like microstructures, and the WAO on the zinc had needle-like nanostructures. Compared with the TENG, which has flat electrodes since the enhancement of electrode surface areas, all of them result in an enlarged output power. Recently, Mohammadpour employed large-area metal oxide semiconductor TiO2 nanotubes (TNTA) as the moving electrodes for the design of a contact-separation mode TENG (Figure 6c).[80] The as-fabricated TENG had a maximum output of 40 V and 1 µA cm−2. To examine how the nanostructured interface tunes the output characteristics, a TENG with a flat thin-film TiO2 electrode was fabricated and measured. The TNTA-based nanostructured TENG demonstrated large induced triboelectric charges (110 nC) per cycle of contact and separation, while the TENG with the flat TiO2 electrode only generated 15 nC charge per cycle. In addition to one-side modification approaches, researchers have developed micro/nanopatterns on both friction layers to further enhance the output performance. Zhang et al. reported the influence of micro–nano dual-scale patterns on TENG output (Figure 7a).[81] Compared to the smooth PDMS filmbased TENG, the micro–nano dual-scale PDMS with pyramidshaped arrays enhanced the output current and voltage of the TENG by over 150% and 100%, respectively. It is understandable that the dual-scale patterns can substantially enhance the roughness of the surface and thus improve the performance of the TENG. Artificially well-designed complex surfaces with the combination of PDMS and a nanostructured Ni electrode were reported by Choi et al., who fabricated these materials through template-assisted nanomolding of PDMS and the

electrodeposition of Ni (Figure 7b).[82] The interlocking faces boost the triboelectricity by enlarging not only the surface contact area but also the duration corresponding to the external friction forces. All four kinds of TENGs were analyzed to evaluate how the surface morphology modulates the output power, especially through the interlocked interface. The results demonstrate a striking growth upon an output current of 23 µA and a voltage of 100 V, whereas the TENG with a flat friction layer only has 0.5 µA under the same measurement conditions. Furthermore, Zheng et al. reported a novel aerogel porous polymer film-based TENG (A-NGs), as shown in Figure 7c.[83] Compared to the similar nonporous polymer film-based TENG (D-NG), the A-NGs, which are composites of spongy polymer films, demonstrate an effective improvement in output performance. This is the first report that employs aerogel porous polymer films as both positive and negative triboelectric materials for TENGs to achieve high performance.

sections.heading: 2.2.2. Molecular Surface Functionalization
sections.text:
As mentioned in Section 2.1, the further away two materials are from each other in the series, the greater the charge transferred. However, for some special application purposes, for example, Kapton, which has good mechanical properties and can be used in harsh environments; does not excel in being charged by triboelectrification.[11,62] Thus, chemical modification is a good strategy that can realize two and more merits in a single material. Combining some appropriate functional groups (such as CF3, NH3, NO3) on the surface to induce easy electron loss or gain through chemical methods and charge injection is the main effective surface modification technique.[49,84–94] In this section, methods concerning chemical functionalization on surfaces are introduced, including their enhancement mechanism toward TENG performance.
Adv. Funct. Mater. 2019, 1900098
Figure 6. a) Gold nanoparticle-enhanced TENG. Reproduced with permission.[78] Copyright 2013, American Chemical Society. b) TENG with nanostructured metal surface using water-assisted oxidation. Reproduced with permission.[79] Copyright 2016, Elsevier. c) TENG based on high surface area TiO2 nanotube arrays. Reproduced with permission.[80] Copyright 2017, WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim.
1900098 (9 of 27) © 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
Zhang et al. first reported chemical modification on a PDMS surface via fluorocarbon (C4F8) plasma, where an ICP system was applied to carry out the necessary treatment.[94] After a series of processes, the PDMS surface was covered by a layer of C4F8 molecules and became rougher. It is noteworthy that the thickness of the C4F8 layer as well as the surface roughness is determined by the reactive time in relation to the TENG performance. Figure 8a shows the output characteristics of TENGs with different reactive cycles. It can be seen that a simple onecycle treatment dramatically boosted the output voltage from 124 to 193 V and that this behavior could be further improved via the use of more treatment cycles, which could be attributed to the increased content of fluorine (F) atoms at the surface. Consequently, the maximum output voltage (265 V) was reached after eight cycles of treatment. Further cycles of treatments cause a decay of output, which could come from two
Adv. Funct. Mater. 2019, 1900098
Figure 7. a) High-output TENG with micro/nano dual-scale patterns on both friction layers. Reproduced with permission.[81] Copyright 2013, American Chemical Society. b) High-performance TENGs with artificially well-tailored interlocked interfaces. Reproduced with permission.[82] Copyright 2016, Elsevier. c) Highly porous polymer aerogel-film based triboelectric nanogenerator. Reproduced with permission.[83] Copyright 2018, WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim.
1900098 (10 of 27) © 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
factors: one is the inhibition of electrostatic induction, and the other is the roughness alternation upon the PDMS surfaces. To identify the effects of the surface groups, first-principles calculations were used to evaluate the vertical ionization energy of PDMS before (8.98 eV) and after (12.31 eV) C4F8 plasma treatment, demonstrating that processed PDMS has an enhanced electron binding energy, which makes the PDMS surface gain electrons easily.
Adv. Funct. Mater. 2019, 1900098
Figure 8. a) Chemical modification on PDMS surface via fluorocarbon plasma. Reproduced with permission.[94] Copyright 2014, Elsevier. b) The improvement of triboelectric charge density based on PET substrate via ICP modification technique. Reproduced with permission.[86] Copyright 2015, WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim.
1900098 (11 of 27) © 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
In addition, conventional TENG materials, such as PET and Kapton, are also investigated to test their triboelectric enhancement after fluorocarbon plasma treatment. Li et al. reported an improvement in triboelectric charge density based on a PET substrate via the ICP modification technique.[86] In their report, although a mixture of O2 and CF4 took place with C4F8 gas as the plasma source, it could also yield chemical modification by fluorination as well as physical engineering through roughening the polymer surface at the nanoscale. The opencircuit output voltage, short-circuit output current, and charge transfer degree of the modified PET reached ≈220 V, 45 µA and 130 nC, respectively, which are more than 200% greater than the corresponding values of the untreated film, as shown in Figure 8b. Surprisingly, the output performance of the TENG based on treated PET is even better than that of the TENG based on the pure PTFE film, which can be considered one of the most efficient polymer materials with the strongest capability to gain electrons. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), atomic force microscopy (AFM), and scanning Kelvin probe force microscopy (KPFM) methods were performed to analyze the modified surface for a deeper understanding. AFM indicates that the unprocessed PET surface was extremely flat. The average roughness was only 2.2 nm, and the corresponding root-mean-square roughness was 2.8 nm. Meanwhile, after one cycle of plasma treatment, the roughness values increased to 27.4 and 34.4 nm, respectively. Moreover, the surface potential of the film was substantially elevated from 41 mV to over 100 mV through the ion plasma reaction due to the increased surface charge density, which comes from not only the chemical surface modification but also the improved surface area. Moreover, an energetic fluorine peak can be found at the full survey spectrum of the plasma-treated PET thin film, while none of the fluorine peaks can be observed from the untreated PET sample. Shin et al. proposed another method to effectively modulate the triboelectric polarity at the surface of PET films, by which the surface was engineered with CF3 groups (negatively charged) coming from trichloro(1H,1H,2H,2H-perfluorooctyl) silane (FOTS) vapor and poly-l-lysine (PLL) solution and with amino group NH3 (positively charged).[90] Figure 9a displays the modification process where PET substrates are cleaned and subsequently modified with oxygen plasma for 100 s, thus forming reactive OH groups their surfaces. Then, one plasma-treated PET film was dipped in PLL solution for 5 min, while the other was placed in FOTS vapor at 95 °C for 1 h. During this processing step, target molecules (PLL and FOTS) are stuck to the surface of PET by bonding together with OH groups. This surface modification can be verified by analyzing the water contact angles of the original and processed specimens by the classic sessile drop technique. The contact angles of the original, PLL-treated (P-PET), and FOTS-treated PET (F-PET) films are 81°, 44°, and 123°, respectively, demonstrating that surface modification can dramatically change hydrophobic and hydrophilic properties. After chemical modification, F-PET (P-PET) shows an outstanding capability to gain (lose) electrons because of the active groups at the surface. Typically, TENGs with hydrophilic and hydrophobic triboelectric surfaces can improve electric output performance due to the large variation between the triboelectric polarities. Figure 9b compares the output voltage and current of TENGs with various friction material pairs: i) original PET: original PET, ii) original PET: P-PET, iii) original PET: F-PET, and iv) P-PET: F-PET. Among these materials, the maximum Voc is ≈330 V, which is produced in pair iv) under an external force of
Adv. Funct. Mater. 2019, 1900098
Figure 9. a) Surface activation process. b) The electrical performance of different contact pairs of the TENGs. c) Cycle tests within one month. a–c) Reproduced with permission.[90] Copyright 2015, American Chemical Society.
1900098 (12 of 27) © 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
0.5 MPa. For comparison, only 4 V is achieved in pair i), which is less than 1/80 of the best one. The pair with one-sided P-PET ii) or F-PET iii) has a Voc of 110 or 205 V, respectively, which is between the maximum and minimum triboelectric polarity differences. Therefore, the power of TENGs can be enhanced by more than 10 000 time by modulating both surfaces to opposite triboelectric polarities, implying the outstanding effectiveness of these amino and fluorine functionalization methods. This electric output was capable of lighting a maximum of 250 commercial LEDs in series by using a rectified circuit to convert alternating current to direct current. Moreover, the surface of the functionalized PET demonstrates superior stability because of the tightly connected chemical bonds at the surface. As shown in Figure 9c, no reduction in output voltage or shortcircuit current can be found after recurring measurements over 4 weeks for the TENG with pair iv). This method can extensively expand the scope of substrate material choices and upgrade the performance of TENGs.
The self-assembled monolayer (SAM) method, wherein the chemical adsorption of an active surfactant on a solid surface is used to realize well-ordered molecular assembly, which is of importance, can be easily performed and widely utilized on various types of surfaces.[95] Wang et al. harnessed SAMs as a useful room temperature chemical approach to improve the performance of TENGs.[92] This method is effective not only on noble-metal substrates but also on insulating substrates. Regarding the former materials, the formation of SAM-modified surfaces begins with the fabrication of gold thin films (≈100 nm) on Kapton substrates (Figure 10a). After thiolbased SAM treatment processing in solutions containing various types of thiols for 12 h, there is formation of the desired functional groups (hydroxyl, ester, amine, and chloro) on the Au surface. The S–2p peak characterized by XPS can be observed in all of the thiol-treated surfaces except the pristine Au surface, indicating that the assembly of the designed ordered molecules is successful on treated surfaces after the abovementioned steps (Figure 10b). Next, a functionalized Au
substrate and FEP layer were coupled as a pair of triboelectric surfaces to examine the performance after modification. In Figure 10c, it is clear that there was a significant enhancement in device output due to the functionalization with amine groups, and accordingly, the output power was raised more than four times. The increased output power upon functionalization with these groups ranks from low to high in the following order: hydroxyl (#2), ester (#3), and amine from 4-aminothiophenol (#4). Interestingly, the engineering process with the chloro functional group (#6) cause a weak decrease in the output performance of the TENG compared with the pristine material, resulting from a lower induced triboelectric charge density because of the surface potential decrease. Moreover, they further demonstrated that such a method can also be applied to insulating triboelectric surfaces (such as SiO2), as summarized in Figure 10d. In this case, one kind of silane molecule, (3-aminopropyl) triethoxysilane (APTES), was chosen to fabricate a SAM through three OSi bonds for each of the molecules. For a TENG with a onesided pristine SiO2 surface, the open-circuit voltage and the surface charge density are ≈150 V and ≈34 mC m−2, respectively. By contrast, after functionalization in 10% APTES solution, these values can correspondingly increase to ≈240 V and ≈51 mC m−2 since more triboelectric charges were generated during contact.
Ion injection, another new chemical modification method for introducing surface charges, can be accomplished with the assistance of a special instrument (air-ionization gun). Ions with opposite polarities are generated by triggering the air discharge inside the gun and are subsequently implanted onto contact surfaces. This method was recently reported for the first time by Wang et al. and managed to effectively improve TENG output performance.[91] A simplified view of the ion injection process is shown in Figure 11a. In contrast, the negative ions (CO3−, NO2−, NO3−, O2−, and O3−) are gradually injected into the top surface of the FEP substrate by an air-ionization gun. At the same time, the positive charges will be induced at the top
Adv. Funct. Mater. 2019, 1900098
1900098 (13 of 27) © 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
electrode and flow from the ground electrode to eliminate the electric field generated by the negative injected charges. Consequently, both the surface of FEP and the back electrode are full of triboelectric charges with the same density but opposite signs. Figure 11b demonstrates the change in the short-circuit charge density of the TENG based on the FEP film after different injection times. In the original state, the contact electrification only generated triboelectric charges on the FEP surface. After the ions were injected into the FEP gradually, the surface charge density increased step by step. According to the measured surface charge density of the TENG before and after ion injection, a 500% improvement in the surface charge density is achieved through this technique, which would lead to a proportional increase in both VOC and short-circuit transferred current density (JSC). As revealed in Figure 11c, the as-made device only produces a VOC of ≈200 V before ion injection. When surface charge density (σsc) reached its maximum value (240 µC m−2) by the modification technique, the VOC can be marvelously boosted to ≈1000 V.

sections.heading: 2.3. Modulating Bulk Friction Materials
sections.text: In addition to surface engineering, modulating the properties of bulk friction materials to enhance TENG performance has drawn extensive interest from researchers, and the methods for achieving this objective mainly include doping nanomaterials and inserting sublayers.[42,96–110] Both of these approaches and their influence on the output performance of TENGs will be presented in this part.

sections.heading: 2.3.1. Doping Nanomaterials into Bulk Friction Materials
sections.text:
One convenient method is to efficiently dope with nanomaterials (0D, 1D, or 2D materials) that can capture electrons readily. Typically, monolayer molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) is a competitive candidate as a charge-trapping agent due to its quantum confinement effect, appropriate energy level and large specific surface area.[111,112] Wu et al. placed monolayer MoS2 into the
Adv. Funct. Mater. 2019, 1900098
Figure 11. a) Main process of the ion injection on the FEP film. b) Elevation of the ∆δSC generated by the TENG when the FEP film was injected with ions time-by-time. c) Enhancement of the TENG’s output performance by the ion injection method. a–c) Reproduced with permission.[91] Copyright 2016, WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim.
1900098 (14 of 27) © 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
TENG friction materials as triboelectric electron acceptor layers to tune the outputs, as displayed in Figure 12a.[107] The highmagnification transmission electron microscopy (TEM) image clearly shows that MoS2 has a honeycomb structure, confirming that the majority of the exfoliated MoS2 sheets are monolayers. Figure 12b also illustrates the rectified voltage of the TENG with or without filling monolayer MoS2. For comparison, it is obvious that the open-circuit voltage of the plain TENG reaches ≈30 V, while that of the TENG with the optimized monolayer MoS2 filling ratio can reach over 400 V. Moreover, the shortcircuit current of the optimized modified TENG also prevails over that of the TENG without MoS2 filling, as shown in Figure 12b. The authors attribute such a dramatic increase in TENG electrical output to the efficient electron capture process in monolayer MoS2, which not only features relatively large specific surface areas but also can suppress the loss of as-generated triboelectric electrons (Figure 12c).
Wen et al. designed a remarkably enhanced TENG by using nanocomposite films made of PVDF and titania monolayers (TOMLs).[105] The TOMLs are capable of being not only good charge trapping materials but also high dielectric fillings. The composite film fabrication process is described in detail in Figure 12d. It is clear from the scanning electron microscopy (SEM) image that the TOMLs are well dispersed in the PVDF matrix film. Figure 12e gives the electric output of the TENG based on TOMLs/PVDF with various weight concentrations of TOMLs from 0% to 2%. It is noted that all output performances increase at first and then decreases with increasing TOML weight ratio. When the weight of the TOMLs is 1.5%, the output voltage and current density of the TENG reach the maximum values of 52.8 V and 5.7 µA cm−2, which are 2.4 and 7.8 times greater than those of the TENG based on pure PVDF (22 V and 0.73 µA cm−2), respectively. This result can be explained by analyzing the dielectric constant and the decay time τ (the cost time when 1/e charges are remaining), as shown in Figure 12f. For the TOML/PVDF composite with a 1.5% weight ratio of TOML, the τ can reach ≈27 min, yet for a pure PVDF device, it is only 11 min. This difference confirms that adding TOMLs to the PVDF matrix can dramatically capture electrons and provide possibilities for triboelectric charge storage in TOMLs. Furthermore, the increased dielectric constants among tribolayers are also beneficial to boost charge density. Therefore, in this research, the dual functions of doped TOMLs in the bulk PVDF layer jointly result in an enhancement in TENG output performance. In addition, other materials, such as reduced graphene oxide and graphene oxide, were also capable of becoming electron-trapping sites in the bulk layer toward large triboelectric enhancement.[97,101,102,106]
Adv. Funct. Mater. 2019, 1900098
Figure 12. a–c) Enhanced TENG based on MoS2 monolayer nanocomposites acting as electron-acceptor layers. a–c) Reproduced with permission.[107] Copyright 2017, American Chemical Society. d–f) Remarkably enhanced TENG based on flexible and transparent monolayer titania nanocomposite. d–f) Reproduced with permission.[105] Copyright 2018, Elsevier.
1900098 (15 of 27) © 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
Another new kind of modification involves the use of a high dielectric nanomaterial doping technique to raise the relative permittivity εr of the original bulk material. Chen et al. filled a PDMS bulk layer with various dielectric materials, such as SiO2, TiO2, BaTiO3, and SrTiO3 nanoparticles.[96] Figure 13a displays the detailed fabrication process. According to the results in Figure 13b, not only the open-circuit voltage but also the short-current density of composite TENGs is effectively improved by adding high dielectric nanoparticles. However, for the TENGs filled with SiO2, no obvious change in output performance is observed due to PDMS and SiO2 having the same relative permittivity of. The maximum output values are 305 V and 7.18 µA cm2 for the TENG with 10 vol% SrTiO3–PDMS composite film, much larger than those of the TENG based on pure PDMS. This phenomenon can be reasonably ascribed to the—increase in permittivity caused by the constant filling of the higher dielectric particles. Regrettably, the precipitation and agglomeration in the mixed NP/polymer solution are unavoidable since NPs have high surface energy, thus resulting in poor mechanical properties and high dielectric loss when the filling ratio is over a certain value. To resolve this shortcoming, Du et al. first modified BaTiO3 NP surfaces with the organic polymer poly (tert-butyl acrylate) (PtBA) before the PVDF polymer matrix with NPs, as shown in Figure 13c.[99] The core–shellstructured BaTiO3–PtBA nanoparticles are free of agglomeration, thus making the BaTiO3 NPs disperse uniformly in PVDF to maintain high flexibility and low dielectric loss. According to Figure 13d, the TENG based on pure PVDF produced a shortcircuit current of only 0.8 µA cm−2, while the TENG based on BaTiO3 NP fillings generated a short-circuit current in the range from 1.1 to 2.1 µA cm−2 depending on the loading ratio of the BaTiO3–PtBA particles. The enhanced dielectric constant gives rise to this output variation, which can be further verified by theoretical calculation. More importantly, the dielectric loss of each composite PVDF-based TENG is low in the measured frequency range.

sections.heading: 2.3.2. Adding Sublayers into Bulk Friction Materials
sections.text:
Dielectric polymers, as one kind of promising sublayer, were selected for insertion between the bulk friction material and conducting electrode to store triboelectric charges during the contact and separation cycles to increase the surface charge density and thus improve the output performance of the TENG. Cui et al. deliberately added a PS sublayer between the bottom aluminum electrode and PVDF friction layer.[42] The results in Figure 14a indicate that the TENG having the PS sublayer demonstrates a dramatically enhanced charge storage capability that is over seven times greater than that of the TENG without the sublayer. In fact, the thickness of the PS sublayer is the key to modulating the output performance, which is investigated in Figure 14b. As the thickness of the sublayer increased from
Adv. Funct. Mater. 2019, 1900098
Figure 13. a,b) Enhanced performance of TENG by filling high dielectric nanoparticles into sponge PDMS Film. a,b) Reproduced with permission.[96] Copyright 2016, American Chemical Society. c–e) Improved output performance by polymer nanocomposites filled with core–shell-structured particles. c–e) Reproduced with permission.[99] Copyright 2018, American Chemical Society.
1900098 (16 of 27) © 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
3.1 to 14 µm, the surface charge density in PVDF initially grew from 3 to 7.3 nC cm−2 and finally reached a saturated state. To further verify the important contribution of the PS sublayer, the decay times of the surface charges for the two kinds of TENGs with or without the PS sublayer were accordingly compared. The decay time for the pure PVDF device is only ≈22 min. However, after introducing a PS dielectric layer between PVDF and the bottom electrode, the decay time of the TENG increased to 44 h. The dramatically enhanced decay time clearly demonstrates that the massive traps in the PS sublayer can powerfully restrain and efficiently store the flowing electrons. Most likely, the polyimide (PI) dielectric layer reported by Feng et al. also functioned as a charge storage layer and improved the device outputs by one order of magnitude, as elucidated
Adv. Funct. Mater. 2019, 1900098
Figure 14. a,b) The influence of the position and thickness of PS layer on triboelectric performance. c) The comparison of accumulation process and decay process of the triboelectric charge for a pure TENG device (red circle) and a TENG device with PS as sublayer (black square). a–c) Reproduced with permission.[42] Copyright 2016, American Chemical Society. d) High output TENG with polyimide as charge storage layer. Reproduced with permission.[100] Copyright 2017, Elsevier.
1900098 (17 of 27) © 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
in Figure 14d.[100] In this work, the authors also selected PET and paper as the control groups to test charge storage capability. Comparing electrical output among PVDF, PI, PET, and paper revealed that the PI group realized the largest improvement in TENG output, while the paper group causes the lowest enhancement, showing the same trend as the polarity of these materials (the negative polarity series: PVDF, PI, PET, and paper). These results provide some reference and direction for choosing the sublayer material; i.e., a better charge storage property always leads to better output performance of TENGs.
Additionally, conductive materials serving as sublayers have also been reported, which are normally inserted in a bulk friction material as transport layers and form sandwich structures. Lai et al. intentionally embedded ravines, gullies, and crisscrossed Au layers at the supine surface of tribolayers, as shown in Figure 15a.[104] The generated charge density of the Au– PDMS TENG increases to 16.8 nC cm−2, approximately three times higher than that of the TENG without Au assistance. The effect of Au layers was thoroughly inspected, as shown in Figure 15b. The theoretical calculation suggests that the Au inside PDMS serves not only as the passageway but also as the charge trapping agent in the case of the triboelectric charges drifting into the internal space of tribomaterials. The transport layer has an improved charge storage capability and enhances the storage depth of the triboelectric charge. The existence of ravines and gullies in PDMS and crisscrosses in the Au layers jointly benefit the tunneling of charges. Moreover, it is found that when the Au layers decrease from 4 to 0, the transferred charge densities decreased from ≈16.8 to 5.3 nC cm−2, as shown in Figure 15c. This finding inspires the design for highperformance TENGs by embedding an appropriate conductive transport layer. Cui et al. also observed significant performance enhancement by using carbon nanotubes (CNTs) as the transport layer (Figure 15d).[42]
Adv. Funct. Mater. 2019, 1900098
1900098 (18 of 27) © 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
Taking all the above results into account, Cui et al. devised a multilayer composite structure for the friction layer to maximize TENG performance.[98] This structure consists of, from the surface to the top electrode, a charge collection sublayer (CCL), a charge transport sublayer (CTL), and a charge storage and barrier sublayer (CSBL), as demonstrated in Figure 16. The CTL is mainly made up of a PS or poly (vinyl alcohol) (PVA) layer in which a small amount of CNTs was dispersed. Despite the slight enhancement in the conductivity of the positive friction layer, the CTL facilitates the transport of triboelectric charges and also renders the residence of electrons scarce in its structure. This special passageway helps the triboelectric charges move from the contact surface and even weakens the repulsion of charges that will come into the friction layer later. The CSBL is a PS sublayer that has weak carrier mobility and intrinsic carrier concentration but is full of defects. Adding a CTL to the positive friction layer could improve the TENG capacity by 3.7-fold. By properly adding a CTL to both friction layers, the charge capacity of the designed TENG would be able to improve 16.5 times, as shown in Figure 16b. Undoubtedly, such a capacity enhancement in the friction layers results in an outstanding promotion in the performance of as-made devices.

sections.heading: 3. Exploring New Materials for Widespread Applications
sections.text:
The thorough and rapid development of TENGs not only shows great possibilities in conventional fields for harvesting ambient energy but also caters to newly emerging domains,
Adv. Funct. Mater. 2019, 1900098
Figure 16. a,b) High-performance TENG with a rationally designed multiple friction layer structure. Reproduced with permission.[98] Copyright 2018, American Chemical Society.
1900098 (19 of 27) © 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
such as implantable medical robots, bionic skin and wearable electronic devices.[52,113–126] Unlike regular applications, these advanced techniques have strict limitations on the construction of TENGs, placing weight on the exploration of highly compatible materials. For example, when a TENG is employed in implantable medical devices, its components should be either biodegradable or bioabsorbable. The material requirements for bionic skin are transparent and stretchable, while for wearable electronic devices, the material should be woven. Owing to the tireless quest for more functional materials by researchers, TENGs are now prospering in cutting-edge research areas. This section summarizes the preparation and performance of new materials for the above applied fields. It is worth noting that the materials mentioned in this part not only refer to materials that have never been investigated but also to those that already exist but have not yet been used in TENGs.

sections.heading: 3.1. Biodegradable/Bioabsorbable Materials for Implantable Biomedical Application
sections.text:
Kim et al. exploited ecofriendly silk as a friction layer and successfully created a silk nanofiber network-based bioinspired TENG (Silk Bio-TEG). The fabrication process and triboelectric performance of the Silk Bio-TEG are shown in Figure 17a.[127] With the combination of PI membrane and electrospun silk, Silk Bio-TEG can generate a nearly 15 V peak-to-peak voltage.
Inspired by Silk Bio-TEG, Wang et al. developed a biodegradable, cheap, and flexible TENG with many natural materials, such as chitosan, starch, and lignin by.[115] Chitosan is a classic polymer extracted easily from chitin. The starch, lignin, glycerol, and acetic acid in this experiment were chosen to modify chitosan properties. Each selected component is environmentally friendly. By tuning the concentrations of lignin and starch, the authors thoroughly analyzed the chemical and physical properties to optimize triboelectric output performance, as shown in Figure 17b. It can be found that among all of the TENGs, the chitosan nanocomposite-based TENG modified with 10% acetic acid generates the greatest output current and voltage. More importantly, this TENG can be biodegradable, demonstrating its potential application in green power sources by adjusting the chemical and physical properties of related materials and structures.
Furthermore, since this kind of TENG can be biodegradable, it is a good candidate for use in vivo. In 2016, Zheng et al. made a major breakthrough in designing a fully biodegradable TENG, which consists of the synthetic biodegradable polymers (BDPs) poly(lactic-co-glycolic acid) (PLGA), poly(3-hydroxybutyrate-co-3-hydroxyvalerate) (PHBV), and polycaprolactone (PCL) and a magnesium (Mg) film, as shown in Figure 18a.[128] Specifically, these biodegradable TENGs have in vitro output voltages ranging from ≈10 to ≈40 V, which can be simply adjusted through the relative composition (Figure 18b). Computed tomography (CT)
Adv. Funct. Mater. 2019, 1900098
1900098 (20 of 27) © 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
imaging was ultimately used to examine the status of the biodegradable TENGs after implantation. The main structure of the biodegradable TENGs was largely disintegrated after 9 weeks, meaning that even inside the animal body, most of the materials used for fabricating biodegradable TENGs were biodegraded. In addition, Jiang et al. very recently developed another fully bioabsorbable material-based in vivo TENG via natural materials.[129] The main natural bioresorbable polymers (NBPs) used in this report are silk fibroin, cellulose, chitin, rice paper (RP), and egg white (EW). A schematic structure of a typical BD-TENG is displayed in Figure 18d. Specific pairwise combinations for the as-invented BDTENG lead to a wide application range of tunable Voc (from 8 to 55 V) and Isc values (from 0.08 to 0.6 µA). These data suggested that the BD-TENG can readily meet complicated electrical output requirements, such as various voltages for
Adv. Funct. Mater. 2019, 1900098
Figure 18. a–c) Biodegradable TENG with different friction layers and its in vivo biodegradation after 9 weeks. d,e) The fabrication and characterize of fully bioabsorbable natural-material-based TENG. a–c) Reproduced with permission.[128] Copyright 2016, American Association for the Advancement of Science. d,e) Reproduced with permission.[129] Copyright 2018, WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim.
1900098 (21 of 27) © 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
bioelectric stimulation or energy powering of varied devices. In addition, the results in Figure 18e verified the good biodegradability of BD-TENG both in vitro and in vivo. Here, the degradation rate or time of the BD-TENG can be effectively modulated by simply changing the silk fibroin encapsulation layer, highlighting an important and simple technique for designing implantable power sources for long-term or shortterm applications.

sections.heading: 3.2. Functional Yarns/Fibers for Textile TENG
sections.text:
Early textile TENGs (t-TENG) largely depend on commercial cloths that are cut into different sizes with coated metal electrodes and delicately woven for random body motion energy collection.[124,125,130–132] To meet the huge demand for wearable technologies, special yarns/fibers have been developed step by step, which would offer the best building blocks for a textile
Adv. Funct. Mater. 2019, 1900098
Figure 19. a) Schematic diagram illustrating the fabricating process of a fiber-based generator. Reproduced with permission.[54] Copyright 2014, American Chemical Society. b) Fabrication and structure of the textile-TENG through loom weaving of metallic yarns. c) Washing durability tests of the textile TENG. b,c) Reproduced with permission.[133] Copyright 2016, WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim.
1900098 (22 of 27) © 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
TENG, as they could be easily assembled into fabrics through weaving.
A TENG fabricated with a core–shell-structured fiber as the basic unit was first reported by Wang and co-workers.[54] This novel fiber-based TENG can transfer mechanical energy from random human vibrations and/or motions to electrical power through the triboelectric electrification of fibers fabricated by using carbon nanotubes and cotton threads as the core layer, as well as PTFE polymer for the shell layer, as presented in Figure 19a. Under the operating conditions, the maximum power density in the test was approximately 0.1 µW cm−2. Subsequently, Zhao et al. rationally developed a series of triboelectric fibers to fabricate machine-washable and fabrication-scalable textile TENGs by weaving metallic fibers in traditional fabric weaving techniques for the first time.[133] Figure 19b features the fabrication procedures and structure of t-TENG. All the materials in this work can be found in the textile industry, and the device is briefly made by miniaturized industrial machineries, achieving marvelous compatibility with high-throughput textile processing. During the power generation process, triboelectric charges can be produced on the contact surfaces of yarn crisscross intersections within the slight touch, facilitating energy conversion from mild or even subtle human motions. A maximum short-circuit current density of 15.50 mA m−2 was realized by the optimized TENG with the weaving fiber. Note that this kind of textile displays good washing ability, can withstand machine washing and can remain stable (Figure 19c). Moreover, a highly stretchable and washable textile TENG was brilliantly woven by Dong et al. based on silicone rubber.[134] Very recent, Yu et al. further promoted the TENG textile technique, aiming to simulate the characteristics of real cloth, such as scalable fabrication, washability, and tailorability.[135] They proposed a strategy for preparing a TENG based on core–shell-yarn textiles as power clothes. Here, triboelectric yarn is fabricated simply by choosing not only artificial polymer fibers but also natural fibrous materials to coil tightly around the core conductive fibers, as demonstrated in Figure 20a. Considering the scarce difference from common yarns, a commercially available weaving method is likewise suitable for this ingenious TENG textile. Remarkably,
Adv. Funct. Mater. 2019, 1900098
1900098 (23 of 27) © 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
the peak VOC of samples could steadily remain at ≈32 V even after 120 washes, indicating its excellent washing durability (Figure 20b). More importantly, the TENG textiles in the test can be casually tailored into assorted styles and sizes, as shown in Figure 20c. This distinct tailorability endows this TENG with the versatility to fulfill unimaginably complicated fashion garment designs.

sections.heading: 3.3. Conductive Material for Stretchable TENG
sections.text:
Strictly speaking, the idea of a stretchable TENG has just emerged in the past few years. One nerve-wracking challenge lies in the selection and fabrication of a stretchable conductive material that could be embedded either in a bulk dielectric material simply as an electrode to harvest electricity or on the surface of a bulk dielectric material as a bifunctional part, i.e., friction layer and electrode.
Percolating silver nanowire (AgNW) networks are a good choice for conducting matrices because of their advanced properties, such as higher stretchability, easy manufacturability, conductivity, low cost, and flexibility.[119] In this work, AgNWs were uniformly embedded in silicone rubber to construct a single electrode TENG. The TENG demonstrates bi- and uniaxial stretching ability of more than threefold elongation and the ability to endure multiple folds, twists, or even various larger deformations, as presented in Figure 21a. On the other hand, when contacting the PDMS layer, CNT network exhibits excellent properties, conductivity and stretchability. Bao and coworkers therefore blazed another trial on CNT-based TENGs (Figure 21b).[136] Accordingly, this CNT-based TENG could generate an open-circuit voltage and short-circuit current of on the order of volts and ten or more µA cm−2, respectively. In addition to these processed precursors, carbon black was also selected as the electrode to construct a fully enclosed soft TENG (Figure 21c).[137] It is well known that the resistance of such stretchable electrodes increases with elongation; however, such deviation does not decrease the triboelectric performance of the TENG due to its ultrahigh impedance. In addition, carbon grease and liquid galinstan were also investigated as stretchable electrodes in other reports.[138–140]
In addition to the abovementioned materials, ionic conductors have been developed to further improve the stretchability of TENGs in order to overcome both the largely enhanced sheet resistance and the loss of percolation under large external strains. A TENG with an extreme stretchability up to 700% was obtained by Parida et al. without performance degradation by using slime as the ionic current collector (Figure 21d).[141] PVA and sodium tetraborate were used to synthesize the special slime used in this report. The high ionic conductivity (2.9 × 10−5 S cm−1) of the produced slime could be attributed to two factors: the presence of positive (Na+) and negative ions (B(OH)4−) dramatically boost charge flow, while the 3D PVA network provided the necessary path for ion transport. For the first time, Pu et al. reported a TENG with ultrahigh stretchability (up to 1160%, Figure 21e).[51] These flexible skinlike TENGs can generate a maximum open-circuit voltage of 145 V with an instantaneous power density of 35 mW m−2. At the same time, these TENG-based electronic touch sensors can
examine a tiny pressure of 1.3 kPa, meeting daily operation requirements.

sections.heading: 4. Summary and Perspective
sections.text:
In this review, recent progress in the development of material candidates for TENG is systematically summarized, including primary component optimization and functional structure exploration. Regarding the ongoing efforts toward improving TENG performance, we anticipate that there will be significant advances in the near future. In fact, this newly developed branch acts as a complementary or even indispensable part of the energy field, aiming to make up for daily consumption and push emerging technology further. It is conceivable that this technique could have a drastic impact on our daily lives and even lead to a paradigm shift for current applications.
To strive for a highly optimized and multifunctional TENG device, certain issues and constraints should be handled carefully. In essence, the following research aspects shall give some inspiration and need to be seriously taken into account.
1. The mechanical behavior of the microstructure versus the counter friction layer that significantly correlates with the output performance is still lack, resulting in the output generated by the same microstructure working in different working modes being incomparable and difficult to predict. To overcome these issues, more mechanics are welcomed to join the TENG research field, and the correlation between microstructural properties and triboelectric properties will be expected through simulation calculations. 2. Although the effect of functional groups on friction charges is remarkable, the mechanisms how the different functional groups influence the friction charges are unclear with a few expectations, e.g., CF3, NH2, NO. To tackle this problem, it is necessary to modify the surface of friction materials through different groups and compare their outputs, on the basis of which we compare the impact of the affinity of different groups, steric hindrance, spatial configuration, and other factors on the triboelectric performance. During the study, a variety of in situ measurement techniques, such as in situ Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), need to be used to characterize and clarify the essential law of the influence of the groups on the charging process. 3. Bulk friction material modification has demonstrated promising results in recent years. However, the mechanism of the doping material, the inner interface and the bulk material collaboratively enhanced the effective transfer, capture and storage of triboelectric charge has not yet been well studied, which have great guiding significance for improving the performance and stability of TENGs. Thus, more works should be focused on the relationship between essential factors and charge storage (maximum surface charge density), charge accumulation rate, and charge attenuation rate in future research, mainly including polymer components, the thickness of the sublayer, the concentration of nanoparticles added, the interfacial molecular functional groups, the interfacial molecular configuration, the interface area, and the conductive network density.
Adv. Funct. Mater. 2019, 1900098
1900098 (24 of 27) © 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
4. TENGs with diversified operation modes and structural design have displayed the potential in a variety of application scenarios, which is the most prominent feature of TENGs different from traditional generators. Therefore, it is extremely valuable and challenging to further explore new materials not only with high triboelectric properties but also compatibility with the application scenarios. Chemical synthesis and doping may address this problem.

metadata.abstractText: Triboelectric phenomena can be observed everywhere; however, they are consistently omitted from applications. Although almost all substances exhibit a triboelectrification effect in daily life, chemists as well as materials scientists have performed extensive investigations in both the aspects of basic science and practical applications to promote the development of triboelectric nanogenerators (TENGs). Here, a detailed survey of materials engineering for high triboelectric performance and multifunctional materials toward specific applications is summarized, including constructing micro/ nanostructures, chemically modifying the frication surface, modulating bulk friction materials, the mechanism for improved performance, and preparing materials for implantable medical devices, bionic skin, and wearable electronic devices. Moreover, an in depth discussion of the current challenges and future efforts for strengthening the performance of TENGs is elaborated in detail, which will better guide new researchers toward a deeper understanding of and explorations about TENGs.
